posts.author: onenewspage.com
posts.title: Ford CEO Expresses Interest In Working With Trump; Says Less Regulation Is Key To Saving U.S. Jobs
posts.text:
With Carrier setting the precedent for what future negotiations with the Trump administration may look like, Ford CEO Mark Fields has come forward to layout potential policy changes that would be important to preserving auto jobs in the United States. Not surprisingly, per an interview with Bloomberg, Fields' opening "ask" focused on *less restrictive fuel economy standards, new currency-manipulation rules to promote free and fair trade and corporate tax reform.*



Ford Motor Co. was a target of Donald Trump ’s criticism on the campaign trail for building cars in Mexico, and now that Trump will be president, *Ford said it’s willing to work with him to keep jobs in the U.S. -- provided Trump puts the right policies in place, according to the automaker’s chief executive officer.*


*“We will be very clear in the things we’d like to see,”* Mark Fields said in an exclusive interview Friday at Bloomberg offices in Southfield, Michigan.


Among them, according to Fields: *currency-manipulation rules to promote free and fair trade, tax reform and safety guidelines for autonomous vehicles.*


Fields said that Ford *plans to lobby the new president to soften U.S. and state fuel-economy rules*. They hurt profits by forcing automakers to build more electric cars and hybrids than are warranted by customer demand, he said.


*“In 2008, there were 12 electrified vehicles offered in the U.S. market and it represented 2.3 percent of the industry,” *Fields said in the interview. *“Fast forward to 2016, there’s 55 models, and year to date it’s 2.8 percent.”*



Of course, Ford was a frequent target of Trump's during the 2016 campaigning cycle after they announced plans to move their small car production to a new facility in Mexico. That said, Fields noted that Trump's policies "*in terms of his economic policies, whether it’s tax reform or otherwise"* have already gone a long way toward influencing Ford's decision to maintain the production of the Lincoln MKC at a plant in Louisville, KY. 



After the Nov. 8 election, *Trump phoned Executive Chairman Bill Ford to discuss the carmaker’s plan to move manufacture of the Lincoln MKC sport utility vehicle to Mexico from a plant in Louisville, Kentucky, Fields said*. The discussion helped convince Ford to keep building the Lincoln in the U.S.


Trump influenced the decision *“because of what he’s talking about in terms of his economic policies, whether it’s tax reform or otherwise,”* Fields said.




As our readers are certainly aware, North American auto OEMs and their tier 2 suppliers have been in a *race to move auto production across borders to low-cost countries (LCCs)* for the past couple of decades as soaring wages, pension and OPEB obligations, high taxes and punitive regulations have made production in the U.S. all but impossible. * *

Of course, the groundwork for the shift of auto production to Mexico was laid with the passage of NAFTA in 1993 by former President Bill Clinton (a fairly inconvenient fact that Hillary probably regrets pretty heavily right now). Since then, Mexico has been a huge beneficiary of automotive plant relocations with offsetting closures coming from the U.S. and Canada. A recent chart from the Wall Street Journal, perfectly illustrates the transition of production capacity to our southern neighbor. 


Meanwhile, with wages that are a fraction of those paid in the U.S. and an accommodative regulatory structure, it's no surprise that the U.S. has lost a substantial number of automotive manufacturing jobs to Mexico.



*Ford is scheduled to open a new $1.6 billion small-car assembly factory in San Luis Potosí in 2018 and hire 2,800 workers*. People familiar with the matter say Ford will produce its Focus there, which is currently built in Michigan.


A contract reviewed by The Wall Street Journal puts *factory wages at the facility at about $1.15 to $2.30 per hour*, on par with what other auto-assembly plants currently pay in the region. *The move to Mexico will yield cost savings of about $1,300 per vehicle, or about $300 million a year*, according to manufacturing experts familiar with the Detroit car maker’s finances.




And while Trump continues to engage in meaningful conversations with company CEOs that have already yielded positive results for Midwest manufacturing employees, here is another look back to just a few short months ago to when Obama said it was all impossible (well, impossible absent a "magic wand" anyway). Enjoy.

posts.title: Ford: England far from finished product
posts.text:
View photos
Despite ending the year without a loss, George Ford insisted there is still room for improvement from England. More Fly-half George Ford has warned the rest of the world that England are nowhere near their best, despite ending the year unbeaten on Saturday.
England were forced to dig deep against Australia, rallying in the second half to beat the Wallabies 37-21 at Twickenham.
The result marked a 14th match unbeaten - equalling an England record set during Clive Woodward's time in charge.
Despite England's undefeated streak, Ford insisted there is a lot of room for improvement.
"I think that's the frustrating thing," Ford said. "We are nowhere near our best.
"There is loads of improvement in us. If we can get anywhere near we think we can, we will be a dangerous team.
"We are going in the right direction for sure and that is the exciting thing, we are still winning games along the way."
England's transformation under head coach Eddie Jones has been evident.
The English have not lost since losing to the Wallabies at the Rugby World Cup in 2015, which spelled the end for former boss Stuart Lancaster.
"It's been great. You always want to be part of winning teams," Ford said.
"Over the past year, we have done that. We have come a long way, our game has development. There are still some areas of improvement so to be part of that is great."
"Not at all," he said. "Ever since we have been working, it was about winning every game.
"We haven't had much of a focus on records, never spoke about it, so we are just thinking about the next job now."
Asked if setting a record for 15 games undefeated was high on the agenda, Marland Yarde added: "Not at all. Ever since we have been working, it was about winning every game.
"We haven't had much of a focus on records, never spoke about it, so we are just thinking about the next job now."

thread.title: 2-peat title: Ford scores 3 TDs as Falcons win another
thread.title_full: 2-peat title: Ford scores 3 TDs as Falcons win another

posts.author: Mike Scandura Contributing writer
posts.title: 2-peat title: Ford scores 3 TDs as Falcons win another
posts.text:
2-peat title: Ford scores 3 TDs as Falcons win another Saturday Dec 3, 2016 at 9:46 PM Dec 3, 2016 at 9:46 PM 2-peat title: Ford scores 3 TDs as Falcons win another By Mike ScanduraContributing writer 
FOXBORO – Whoever said youth is wasted on the young didn’t have Mashpee’s Devaun Ford in mind. 
Ford, a sophomore, shredded Wahconah’s defense as the Falcons cruised to their second consecutive Super Bowl victory on Saturday, 34-13, in the Division 4 bowl at Gillette Stadium. 
Not only did Ford carry the ball 17 times for 120 yards and two touchdowns but he also caught two passes for 33 yards and one score. And for good measure he caught a two-point conversion pass from quarterback Nick Carpenter. 
“Devaun Ford wants to be here,” Mashpee coach Matt Triveri said. “He believes he belongs here. He has a lot of talent. I know people pull him in different directions but he’s in a real good place. 
“He gets after it. He wants the football. He wants to be the guy that the pressure’s on. That’s what winners are. That’s what big-time players are and he’s a big-time player.” 
When the final whistle blew, Ford had finished the season with 162 total points, 25 rushing touchdowns and nine touchdown receptions. 
“I’ve always had confidence in myself but I never thought as a sophomore I would end the season with so many touchdowns and win a Super Bowl,” Ford said. “That’s unreal especially after winning one last year (in Division 6). 
“I did not think we were going to win one again.” 
Carpenter also did his part to ensure Mashpee (12-1) would earn consecutive titles. 
A senior, Carpenter completed just 3 of 9 passes for 43 yards, but one went for a touchdown. He ran for 47 yards and one touchdown on only four carries and he also ran for a two-point conversion. 
“He has 35 career wins,” Triveri said. “I don’t know where he ranks, but he has to be one of the top 10 winningest quarterbacks in the state’s history. 
“He was playing quarterback for us at 5-6 and 140 pounds as a freshman. The only thing he does is win games.” 
Carpenter made his presence felt on both sides of the ball late in the first quarter. 
After the Warriors (10-2) had driven to Mashpee’s 20, Carpenter intercepted a Will Geneway pass and returned it 24 yards. Carpenter then sprinted 47 yards and Ford covered the last 15 yards for a 6-0 lead. 
“That was a huge momentum shift,” Ford said of Carpenter’s pick. “Nick came up and made a great play. We were in our red zone. When he made that play it turned the whole intensity around. 
“That’s what led us to this win. He’s a leader.” 
Mashpee maintained its 6-0 lead until the latter stages of the second quarter when Geneway dashed 47 yards around right end and Pat Butler kicked the PAT. 
The Falcons countered with a drive of their own which featured two of three roll-the-dice calls by Triveri. 
On fourth and nine from the Wahconah 39, Carpenter completed a 10-yard pass to Dominick Fellini, which gave Mashpee a first down at the 29. 
Then, on fourth-and-five from the 7, Carpenter threw a seven-yard touchdown pass to Ford for a 12-7 lead at halftime. 
“You have to make plays,” Triveri said. “In those situations you have to come through. These guys have done nothing but come through their whole careers. 
“As for this senior class, we weren’t really sure where they were going to be at the end of last year. There wasn’t a lot of leadership and there wasn’t a lot of effort at times in the offseason. But they absolutely have come through in the greatest way.” 
The Warriors tested the Falcons leadership when they received the second half kickoff and covered 73 yards in nine plays with Geneway bolting nine yards up the middle for a 13-12 lead. 
But that margin lasted only 6.5 minutes, which was the amount of time it took for Mashpee to regain the lead. 
With Ford and Jack Rodriguez leading the way, Mashpee marched 67 yards in 13 plays with Carpenter wedging over from the 1 on fourth-and-goal, which marked the third time the Falcons executed on a key fourth-down play. 
Wahconah’s first drive of the fourth quarter was stymied by Mashpee’s defense, which included a sack of Geneway by Jake Johnston. 
The Falcons eventually took over on their 33 and Ford started left, cut to his right and sprinted 36 yards for a touchdown and a 28-13 lead. 
Wahconah made an attempt to reduce its deficit when it marched from its 35 to the Mashpee 20. But on fourth-and-7, Geneway’s pass fell incomplete. 
Fellini then applied the exclamation point by sprinting 61 yards for a touchdown for the final score. 
“I can’t say enough about these kids,” Triveri said. “I don’t think anyone understands that we’ve won three state titles with less than 40 kids in different divisions. They had 90 kids on the field. 
“It is unbelievable what these kids have done. It’s something I don’t know how many people are going to duplicate with numbers like this.”

thread.title: Virginia Tech notes | Ford back in familiar territory in Orlando | Virginia Tech Football
thread.title_full: Virginia Tech notes | Ford back in familiar territory in Orlando | Virginia Tech Football | pilotonline.com

posts.author: pilotonline.com
posts.title: Virginia Tech notes | Ford back in familiar territory in Orlando | Virginia Tech Football
posts.text:
ORLANDO, Fla. Virginia Tech wide receiver Isaiah Ford didn’t need a tour Saturday of Camping World Stadium in Orlando, Fla., where his Hokies took on Clemson in the Atlantic Coast Conference championship. He was familiar with the place from his high school days.
Ford already had some hardware from games played in the stadium. He was the only player on Tech’s roster trying to win a third championship in Orlando.
In his freshman and senior seasons at Trinity Christian Academy in Jacksonville, Fla., Ford played in high school state championship games in the stadium. Trinity Christian won both state title games.
For the ACC championship game, he was facing an issue he didn’t have to deal with in his previous two visits to the stadium. He didn’t know early in the week exactly how many tickets he needed for the championship game, but with a slew of family and friends planning to attend, he wasn’t turning down any teammates who offered to give him tickets.
“I don’t really have a set number, to be honest,” Ford said Monday.
“Everyone wants tickets, so I’m in a hassle right now trying to ask as many of my teammates and coaches as I can to try to get as many tickets as possible. Just trying to make sure that everyone can come to the game and watch me, because this is the closest that they’ll all be able to get for me probably, so to get as many people there would be really special.”
It turned out tickets likely weren’t difficult for his supporters to obtain.
With the ACC moving the game in late September from Charlotte, N.C., to Orlando as a result of North Carolina’s HB2 laws, ticket sales for the championship game were slow. Disney employees were offered free tickets to the game.
NO INTRO NEEDED
Growing up in Mauldin, S.C., Tech right tackle Jonathan McLaughlin got his share of exposure to Clemson’s football program. He wasn’t offered a scholarship by the Tigers, but he has a loose connection with one of their best players.
McLaughlin remembers playing in high school against Clemson linebacker Ben Boulware, who attended T.L. Hanna High in Anderson, S.C., about 35 miles southwest of Mauldin. Boulware, a 6-foot, 235-pound senior, was a first-team All-ACC pick this season.
“I know he’s a physical guy,” said McLaughlin, a senior who earned third team All-ACC honors this season. “He was a good player in high school, and after I watch the film, he’s a good player on film, as well.”
ANOTHER CITY, ANOTHER ACC TITLE GAME
Tech holds the distinction of being the only ACC team to play a football conference championship game in all four cities that have hosted the title game – Jacksonville, Fla., Tampa, Fla., Charlotte and Orlando.
In 2005, unranked Tech lost 27-22 to No. 5 Florida State in Jacksonville in the inaugural ACC title game. Two years later, No. 6 Tech gained redemption in Jacksonville with a 30-16 conference title game victory against No. 12 Boston College.
In 2008, unranked Tech met No. 18 BC again, with the Hokies coming out on top 30-12 in Tampa to claim the ACC title. Tech was again in the ACC championship in 2010, and No. 12 Tech beat No. 20 FSU in Charlotte 44-33.
VIRGINIA CONNECTIONS
Clemson has three players from Virginia on its roster. All have played significant roles this season.
Redshirt freshman Clelin Ferrell from Richmond starts at defensive end. He came into the championship game with 37 tackles, including 6.5 for losses and four sacks.
True freshman free safety K’Von Wallace from Richmond is No. 2 on Clemson’s depth chart. He had played 108 snaps and recorded six tackles, including one for a loss, entering the title game.
Redshirt freshman linebacker Chad Smith from Sterling played in 11 games in the regular season, leading Clemson with nine tackles on special teams. He had 18 tackles total before Saturday night.
– Norm Wood, The Daily Press

thread.title: Smith, Barbara
thread.title_full: Smith, Barbara

posts.title: Smith, Barbara
posts.text: Barbara SmithApril 11, 1933 - Nov. 29, 2016LEITERS FORD - Barbara Marie Smith, 83, of Leiters Ford, passed away at 11:40 AM on Tuesday, November 29, 2016 in Rock Hill, SC. Barbara was born April 11, 1933 in DeLong. Predeceasing her are her parents, Raymond and Abbie Chapman Thomas, her only sibling, Keith Thomas and a grandson Rick Pac. After graduation from Leiters Ford High School in 1951, Barbara was employed for two years in the office of the Ball Band Plant of Mishawaka. On February 15, 1952, she married the love of her life, Robert Wayne Smith and this union lasted 63 years until his death on May 30, 2015. She was a stay -at-home Mom eleven years for their three sons. Barbara returned to the work force in 1963, this time at the Multi-Graphic printing Company of South Bend and retired from there after 25 years in 1988. They lived on Mayflower Road in South Bend and were members of the Sumption Prairie United Methodist Church. Upon retirement they moved back to Leiters Ford and brought their church membership back to Leiters Ford United Methodist Church. Twenty winters were spent at Villa Del Sol of Avon Park, FL For a number of years Barbara was the secretary/treasurer of the Leiters Ford-Aubbeenaubbee Alumni Association. She also was president of the WSCS group at church; a member of the Golden Key Home Extension Club of Culver and for over sixty years had played Scrabble once a month at the Scrabble Club of South Bend. Left to mourn her passing are her children; Daniel Lee and wife Mary Jo of Mishawaka, Robert Alan of Houston, TX, Paul Wayne and wife Betsy of Rock Hill, SC.; six grandchildren: Dawn Feece, Deann Lanz, Kelly Hayes, Jacob Smith, Jeff Smith, Brooke Smith; 10 great grandchildren: Sydney, Shelby, Alex, Max, Jenna, Olivia, Zachary, Wyatt, Mason, Carter; two great great grandsons: Logan and Weston and many nieces, nephews, cousins and friends. The funeral service will be at 1:00 PM on Wednesday, December 7, 2016 in the Good Family Funeral Home, 1200 West 18th St., Rochester with Pastor Nancy Foster officiating. Friends may visit with the family two hours prior to the service in the funeral home. Interment will be in the Leiters Ford Cemetery. Memorials may be made to the Leiters Ford United Methodist Church, PO Box 126, Leiters Ford, IN 46945 Electronic expressions of sympathy may be made to her family at www.goodfamilyfh.com . Funeral Home

thread.title_full: German Ford Mustang Cop Car Demands You Respect its Authority

posts.author: Motor Trend Staff
posts.title: German Ford Mustang Cop Car Demands You Respect its Authority
posts.text:
German Ford Mustang Cop Car Demands You Respect its Authority Motor Trend 2 days ago Motor Trend Staff German Ford Mustang Cop Car Demands You Respect its Authority For whatever reason, any car ends up being several magnitudes cooler once it's turned into a cop car . The result is the same even when you start with an already cool car, as evidenced by Germany's new Polizei Ford Mustang.
Research 2017 ford mustang See Full Specs See Pricing The special Ford Mustang GT is the German police force's new "Tune it! Safe!" demo car that will be used as an outreach tool to promote safe vehicle modification. The car was commissioned by the Verband der Automobil Tuner (VDAT), essentially Germany's equivalent of the Specialty Equipment Market ( SEMA ), and is sponsored by Germany's Federal Ministry of Transport and Digital Infrastructure, among other organizations. The car was built by Wolf Racing, which tuned the Mustang GT's 5.0-liter Coyote V-8 engine to 440 hp and added custom 20-inch alloy wheels wrapped in Hankook Ventus S1 Evo tires, a height-adjustable coilover suspension, a body kit with front splitter, side sills, rear diffuser, a rear wing, and unique bumpers, and a sports exhaust system.
© Motor Trend Staff Ford Mustang GT Polizei front three quarter 03 The modified Mustang cop car will serve as a sort of liaison to the tuner crowd in Germany, which may otherwise not be all that receptive to a police presence at their events. Though this Polizei pony car won't chase down bad guys on the Autobahn, S550 Mustang interceptors do exist. Mustang tuner Steeda has offered a police package for law enforcement agencies since early this year.
Source: Tune it! Safe!
